NOTICE_DATA.ORIGINAL_CPV: Command and control system, printing, graphics, office automation and information-processing equipment

CODIF_DATA.PR_PROC: Negotiated without a prior call for competition
CODIF_DATA.RP_REGULATION: European Union, with participation by GPA countries
CODIF_DATA.HEADING: 01B15

SHORT_DESCR.P: The University of Manchester intends to purchase a Stereolithography 3D Printing system optimised for materials development.

The equipment will be co-located with the suite of 3D and 2D printing equipment currently in the Manchester Centre for Digital fabrication. The provision of a state of the art facility for materials and process development using stereolithography will complement the existing facilities for inkjet printing, robocasting and extrusion based 3D printing.

D_JUSTIFICATION.P: Will provide fully open source Stereolithography equipment allowing for materials development programmes. The equipment will be of immediate use to existing research programs in the University of Manchester, including collaborative work. It will also fit with work in the SHRI partners. The equipment will be specifically designed and optimised for materials development with full access to machine specific software and as such will be a unique world leading implementation.

INFO_ADD.P: The University of Manchester will be home to a new national research and innovation centre in advanced materials, the Sir Henry Royce Institute (SHRI). Announced by the Chancellor, George Osborne, in the 2014 autumn statement, the GBP 293 000 000 Institute will grow the UK’s world-leading research base in advanced materials research and development, which is fundamental to all industrial sectors and the national economy. The founding partners comprise the Universities of Sheffield, Leeds, Liverpool, Cambridge, Oxford and Imperial College London, along with National Nuclear Labs (NNL) and the Culham Centre for Fusion Energy (CCFE).

ADDRESS_REVIEW_BODY.OFFICIALNAME: The High Court of Justice of England

REVIEW_PROCEDURE.P: The Authority will incorporate a minimum 10 calendar day standstill period at the point information on the award of the contract is communicated through the European Journal. If an appeal regarding the award of the contract has not been successfully resolved, The Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (SI 2015 Nº 102) provide for aggrieved parties who have been harmed or are at risk of harm by breach of the rules to take action in the High Court (England, Wales, and Northern Ireland). The purpose of the standstill period referred to above is to allow the parties to apply to the Courts to set aside the award decision before the contract is entered into.
